clinical_study.brief_title: Alcohol Consumption and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus Risk in Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Association of Light-to-moderate Alcohol Consumption With Risk of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus in Individuals With Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease

brief_summary.textblock: This study explored the cross-sectional and prospective associations between light-to-moderate alcohol consumption (LMAC) and risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

primary_outcome.measure: Light-to-moderate alcohol consumption (LMAC) and risk of prevalent type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)
primary_outcome.description: Fatty liver was assessed by ultrasound. T2DM was defined as the presence of any of the following conditions based on American Diabetes Association criteria: (1) fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥ 7.0 mmol/L; (2) hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) ≥ 6.5%; (3) self-reported clinician-diagnosed T2DM.

secondary_outcome.measure: LMAC and incident risk of T2DM
secondary_outcome.description: Fatty liver was assessed by ultrasound. T2DM was defined as the presence of any of the following conditions based on American Diabetes Association criteria: (1) fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥ 7.0 mmol/L; (2) hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) ≥ 6.5%; (3) self-reported clinician-diagnosed T2DM.

study_pop.textblock: Consecutive Chinese adults underwent annual health examinations in 2009 were enrolled in the cohort study. Follow-up between 2009 and 2018 were obtained in Zhenhai Lianhua Hospital, Ningbo.
